structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: The course will examine the main theoretical debates surrounding core concepts in political theory. It will explore the reasons for enduring disagreements about how to interpret these concepts. It will feature a strong interactive component (in the form of debates, disputes, and discussions) as well as a writing skills dimension via position papers.
description.et: Kursuse keskmes on erinevad teoreetilised seisukohad ja vaidlused poliitikateooria põhimõistete ümber. Kursuse käigus kasutatakse erinevaid meetodeid nii avaliku esinemise kui analüüsioskuse arendamiseks.

objectives.en: This course will provide students with essential grounding in the political theory and ethics related to democracy and governance.
objectives.et: Kursus annab ülevaate demokraatia ja valitsemise poliitikateoreetilistest ja eetilistest alustest.

learning_outcomes.en: Completion of this course will afford students the ability to: (1) understand the origins and relevance of key normative concepts related to democracy and governance (such as power, community, liberty, rights, representation, justice, legitimacy, equality); (2) identify and assess the essential parameters of public ethics related to democracy and governance (corruption, public accountability, rule of law). (3) formulate and communicate their own opinion concerning key normative aspects of democracy and governance via essays and debates.

notes.et: Students of Democracy and Governance MA programme will have priority enrolling in the course.

independent_work.et:
The course will consist of 8 lecture-seminars and 3 debates. Both lecture-seminars and debates require thorough preparation at home. Detailed instructions to independent study and assignments are provided in Moodle.

I strongly encourage you to keep a reading journal in which you record 1) the main point of the article(s) read; 2) seek to determine the author's broader agenda and possible debate in which s/he participates; 3) quote the most startling and interesting ideas that catch your eye in the article as well as 4) jot down your own ideas and questions that this reading prompts in your mind.

description.et:
Participation in debates.
The performance of debating teams will be assessed according to the following criteria: 
a) Organization & Clarity: Main arguments and responses are outlined in a clear and orderly way; 
b) Depth and understanding of the topic. Evidence of thorough research into theoretical issues; 
c) Originality of argument and relevance of examples. Thoughtful engagement with the material; relevance of empirical examples 
d) Use of cross-examination and rebuttal: Rebuttals were specific to opposing team's arguments and expressed with clarity, (identification of weakness in Negative team's arguments and ability to defend itself against attack). 
e) Presentation Style and Adherence to Rules: Tone of voice, clarity of expression, precision of arguments all contribute to keeping audience's attention and persuading them of the team's case; speakers adhered to the rules and time structure of the debate.

Final essay.
Final essays will be assessed according to the following criteria:
a) Positioning: The strength and clarity of the position on the given topic
b) Depth and originality of understanding, engagement with relevant academic literature.
c) Examples: The relevance and development of the examples used to support your argument.
c) Organisation: The organisation of each paragraph and of the essay overall
d) Clarity of expression
f) Oral conversation on the essay - if the student is unable to defend one's argument orally, the essay will not be accepted, and a new essay would need to be submitted. This is to exclude illegitimate use of AI in essay-writing. Clear guidelines about the extent to which the use of AI is permitted in this assignment will be provided.

grade_preconditions.et: All parts of the assessment submitted and performed according to instructions

grade_evaluation.et:
Debate - 15% of the final grade
Participation in seminars and Moodle forums - 40% of the final grade
Essay and oral conversation on the essay - 45% of the final grade

debt_elimination.et: By individual agreement with the instructor.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

resources.recommended_materials: Andrew Heywood, Political Theory. An Introduction (Palgrave: MacMillan, 2015 (4th edition)).

description.et: Introductory Seminar. Political theory, politics, and the state. Challenges of our age.
Seminar. The concept of liberty and liberalism in the post WWII era.
Young and the politics of identity.

Debate I
In the context of Iris Marion Young's philosophy on justice and the politics of difference, is the rise of a surveillance society through digital transformation a threat to or a facilitator of social justice?

Guest lecture 14.00-16.00
"Merging conceptual and digital history to study the transnational evolution of parliamentary democracy"

Debate II
Does digital transformation enhance or inhibit the chances of realising the ideal of deliberative democracy?
The Politics of Anthropocene/ Environmental philosophy
LIberal nationalism, constitutional patriotism, and multiculturalism

Debate III
Is there a human right to immigrate?
